question.body: 1.11 What is XUL? Select one response and write the letter here
question.answer: Much like XIML, XUL is an XML-based user interface markup language, but is not standardized, and does not inter-operate with implementations other than those based on Mozilla's Gecko layout engine.

question.body: 1.12 What is XSL? Select one response and write the letter here
question.answer: XSL stylesheets are similar to CSS stylesheets - but instead of defining the look of a HTML document, they dictate how XML documents should be displayed. XSL also includes a transformation language, XSLT, initially intended for styling operations, but currently used for general purpose XML processing - for example, generating HTML web pages from XML files. XSL is compatible with CSS, but uses a different syntax.

question.body:
1.13 Below is some XML. The last line is missing. What should it be? Select one response and write the letter here
<?xml version="1.0"?> <note> <to>Class</to> <from>Ray</from> <heading>Reminder</heading> <body>Don't forget to complete your Blog!</body>
question.answer: An XML document should be, at the very least, well-formed. To ensure well-formedness, the document should have a single root element. In this case, the root element would be note, but it is not closed; and XML mandates all tags to be closed.
